title: Grant Cederwall
text:
Grant Newton Cederwall (born 4 July 1959) is a <a href="New%20Zealand%20people">New Zealand</a> former <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er and <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player.
Cederwall was born at <a href="Dunedin">Dunedin</a> in July 1959. He made his debut in <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for <a href="Wellington%20cricket%20team">Wellington</a> against <a href="Central%20Districts%20cricket%20team">Central Districts</a> at <a href="McLean%20Park">Napier</a> in the 1978–79 <a href="Plunket%20Shield">Shell Trophy</a>. He played first-class cricket for Wellington until November 1990, making a total of 35 appearances. Playing as an <a href="all-rounder">all-rounder</a>, he scored 794 runs in his 35 first-class matches, at an <a href="batting%20average%20%28cricket%29">average</a> of 19.36 and a highest score of 68. With his right-arm <a href="Seam%20bowling">medium pace</a> bowling, he took 73 wickets at a <a href="bowling%20average">bowling average</a> of 34.08. He took a <a href="five%20wicket%20haul">five wicket haul</a> once, with figures of 7 for 97 against <a href="Northern%20Districts%20cricket%20team">Northern Districts</a> in the 1988–89 Shell Trophy. Cederwall also played <a href="List%20A%20cricket">List A one-day cricket</a> for Wellington, debuting in that format against Central Districts at <a href="Cooks%20Gardens">Wanganui</a> in the 1982–83 <a href="Ford%20Trophy%20%28cricket%29">Shell Cup</a>. He played List A cricket for Wellington until January 1989, making a total of 28 appearances. He was less effective as a batsman in one-day cricket, scoring 199 runs at an average of 10.47, with a high score of 37. With the ball, he took 28 wickets an average of 24.46 and best figures of 5 for 17. These figures, one of two five wicket hauls he took in one-day cricket, came against <a href="Canterbury%20cricket%20team">Canterbury</a> in the 1984–85 Shell Cup. In addition to playing first-class and List A cricket in New Zealand, Cederwall also played <a href="Minor%20Counties%20of%20English%20and%20Welsh%20cricket">minor counties cricket</a> in England for <a href="Bedfordshire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Bedfordshire</a> in 1983, making five appearances in the <a href="Minor%20Counties%20Championship">Minor Counties Championship</a> and a single appearance in the <a href="MCCA%20Knockout%20Trophy">MCCA Knockout Trophy</a>. 
Outside of playing cricket, Cederwall also played <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>, representing <a href="Wellington%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Wellington</a> in a single match in 1979. Cederwall currently works as a real estate agent. In 1999, he was a founding member of the <a href="Wellington">Wellington</a>-based Tommy's Real Estate Ltd. His brother, <a href="Brian%20Cederwall">Brian Cederwall</a>, played rugby union over a hundred times for Wellington.
